respondent.name: BERT FROST, IN HIS OFFICIAL CAPACITY AS ALASKA REGIONAL DIRECTOR OF THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE, ET AL.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument next in Case 14-1209, Sturgeon v. Frost. Mr. Findley.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. --  Mr. Findley, can I ask two quick clarifying questions just so I understand what's at issue here? Your argument applies to the navigable rivers generally; is that right? In other words, to the navigable rivers running through the federally owned Alderson Reporting Company land as well as to those running through the inholdings?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And is there any information in the record about whether your client actually was running his boat on the portions which were -- are within the federally owned parts, or instead it's the inholdings? Is that what you called them?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Was Federal --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Was Federal public land?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Okay. Thank you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Just, again, a preliminary question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is it conceded by all or Alderson Reporting Company is it not that this is navigable -- that these are navigable waters?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And that's not contested here?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So you're claiming a right not merely to use the hovercraft in the nonpublic lands. You're claiming that there's no residual right to control navigable waters in the Federal lands area?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So what do you do about the ANILCA provision that says that boating and other water activities within public lands, within Federal public lands can be regulated?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That's not what it says. It says any waters in the jurisdiction of the United States.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, it could apply to both, is what I'm saying. What says it excludes navigable waters?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I wasn't sure, but I -- I thought maybe they were suggesting that the navigational servitude and its reserved rights were -- were title.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So it -- it -- it may well be, you think, that the Federal government would have authority to do this in the exercise of its navigational servitude even though it doesn't have authority to do it, as you assert, under the Park Service?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay. Do -- do we have to resolve the further question? Whether if the Park Service can't do it somebody else can do it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Suppose you have a regulation or a statute that's applicable to all United States parks. Is it applicable here?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: No, let's say -- let's say first it's a statute, suppose a Federal statute. So you need a permit for a fire in a Federal park. Applicable or -- or -- or not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What was the basis for the Ninth Circuit's decision? Was it limited to navigable waters?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What was the basis for the decision?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Your reading on a practical basis with respect to the navigable waters makes almost no sense to me. I'm looking at a map attached to the petition of the State of Alaska. It's attached to the end of the brief. And it seems like these national parks are spread along the coast of Alaska in a haphazard way, meaning the national parks have Alderson Reporting Company jurisdiction over a small strip along the coast of Alaska. Presumably you're not arguing that this agreement controls the U.S. servitude of navigable waters around those strips.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So you're saying that the U.S. can't control the navigable servitude in any part of that coast.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Can.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And so what do you take the words in -- in 103(c) to mean, the boating exception, when it says "in the jurisdiction of the United States"? "Waters in the jurisdiction"? You don't think navigable waters are within the jurisdiction of the United States in Federal lands? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So if the -- as it often does elsewhere, if the Army Corps of Engineers have issues with respect to things that the State is doing on the navigable waters or, you know, other people are building a -- a -- a damn or a fish -- I forget what they are called -- the Corps of Engineers can come in and say, you can't do that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Let's -- and EPA might -- might be able to prohibit boating, no?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Or environmental --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But it says in the regulation --  look at the regulation. It says, "The Hovercraft Regulation applies to waters subject to the jurisdiction of the United States." This is water subject to the jurisdiction. "Within the boundaries of the National Park Service" --  that's the tougher part -- "including navigable waters." That doesn't help us. So the question, I would think, would be is this portion of the river within the boundaries of the National Park Service? Am I right so far?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, now, you look at what they say about that, and you get, when they're defining the Yukon-Charley River's National Preserve, it says that that national preserve --  which is the whole thing, which includes the section of the river that we're Alderson Reporting Company talking about -- contains public lands. It doesn't say it's identical with the public lands. And then in another place it says, "Only those lands within the portion which are public lands shall be deemed to be included a portion of such unit," not that they make up the whole of such unit. At least we --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What are -- what are you quoting from? I'm --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'm quoting from regulations which are U.S.C. -- I don't know. I'll -- I'll have to show you later, because I'm quoting -- (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: We're going to get into numbers, and I -- I just thought this case is too complicated to ask anything, but you've tempted me. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And so -- so you see -- have you got in your mind what I just quoted?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And then once you have that, you have this regulation applying to this portion of the river. So now we look to the statute to see if Alderson Reporting Company anything there takes away what the regulations seem to give. And the only part of the statute -- though it's an important part -- that supports you is the second sentence. But as I read that second sentence, it says that, "The regulations that apply solely to public lands within such units," you see, "are the ones that don't apply to the private land up in Yukon-Charley. But I've just read you a regulation, which, on my reading of it, is the Hovercraft Regulation, and does not apply solely to public lands within National Park Service units, either in Alaska or anywhere else. And therefore, the statute doesn't stop it. Now, that's -- that's -- and I want to -- I don't know if I can do this orally; I just tried to, which is to put the argument against you as best I could, and I want to hear the reply.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Uh-huh.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, Mr. Findley, I mean --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: -- whether or not that's true, agencies can change their mind about things. And I think that the question that Justice Breyer is putting to you is this question about what this provision means: "Shall be subject to the regulations applicable solely to public lands." I mean, "solely" is a very purposive word, you know? I mean, Congress drops lots of words, but you put "solely" in a sentence when you mean "solely." And this does not apply solely to public lands.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I -- I don't understand why the statute that Justice Breyer is focusing on, that part of the statute. Applies just to park regulations and not to something from the EPA or the Federal Aeronautics Administration. Federal Aeronautics Administration says you can't have a smoke stack more than feet high. Why -- why doesn't that apply?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But it -- it -- it -- but it -- it talks about regulations applicable solely to public lands. But is -- is -- is that all Forest Service regulations? Are you saying that that's a -- the same as Forest Service regulations? Is that what you're saying?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Maybe --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I guess maybe -- maybe you can explain that to me. But it seems to me that if you took it out of the statute, what you would have was to something that says no private lands shall be subject to the regulations applicable to public lands. And that's what you should want. If -- if it had said that, no private lands shall be subject to the regulations applicable to public lands, you wouldn't be here. You would have won your case already. But it doesn't say that. It says, "No private lands shall be subject to the regulations applicable solely" -- exclusively, only -- "to public lands."

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: So you're saying that the word "solely" distinguishes between statutes like the Clean Air Act and park land statutes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Because I understand why Congress might have wanted to distinguish between, like, the Clean Air Act and park statutes. But putting the word "solely" in, I got to say, does not do that for me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, tell me the imperfect way.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, no. How does that do that? No, seriously. How does that distinguish between two different kinds of generally-applicable statutes, Alderson Reporting Company one generally applicable in applying to park lands and not park lands, and another generally applicable in the sense of applying to both public and private lands within parks.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Miss Botstein.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: By "inholdings," you Alderson Reporting Company include the submerged lands that were conveyed to the State upon statehood?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Right. Now, is there any basis for distinguishing the submerged lands from the --  I don't know what to call it --  from the land land that are in the other inholdings or do you understand the government's argument to be that they are treated the same?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What does that do to Federal right to control, whether it's titled or not, all navigable waters?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Repeat what you said. I didn't quite hear it or understand it. I'm sorry. Say it again.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, suppose there were a Coast Guard regulation that -- applicable to all throughout the United States. Could that be applied to this river?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, why is the -- so you're -- you're just saying that the Park Service lacks authority to promulgate this regulation quite without regard to this statute, which doesn't help me very much. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So you're not --  I'm sorry. You're not saying that the Coast Guard couldn't come in and say no hovercrafts around the Alaskan coast.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: How about if they wanted to say, in this alcove, the Coast Guard, not the Park Service, says you can't have hovercrafts, that would be okay?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: If I understand what you're saying, you're saying with respect to a river that's smack in the middle of federally owned lands, okay, a river that's in the middle of federally owned lands, what cannot happen is that the EPA can't come in and say there's some terrible pollution in this river, and we need to address it. That would be off limits?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why? I mean --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: The Coast Guard can do it. The EPA can do. It's only the Park Service that can't do it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And I guess part of my question about this is, I look at that map, you know, and that map of this area has all this green land, which green represents real Federal park land, and there's a river that runs through it. And -- and you're saying Alderson Reporting Company that that river that runs through the park land, and nobody can do anything on -- or the Feds can't do anything on? I mean, this isn't the inholdings. I mean, I can understand the argument with respect to the inholdings and the rivers that are running through the inholdings. But this is the rivers that are running through the park land. Now, it seems to me a very strange thing that Congress would have created Federal lands in a Federal park land but said that the Federal Park Service can't have anything to do with the rivers. The rivers are like an important part of the park, aren't they?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But that's not true as to navigable waters. The Federal government can regulate navigable waters.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: As I read it --  as I read it, it's complicated, but in a sense it's simple. Yosemite has some private land within it and a lot of Alderson Reporting Company public. You know, there's some houses in Yosemite owned by private people. There are interior regs that apply to all of Yosemite, such as certain fireplace regs. There are some that only apply to the park but not the private people. What this statute says is the latter. Doesn't deprive --  apply to that land that you gave to Alaska. That's what the statute says. And what the reg says is that our hovercraft reg applies to everything within Yosemite, if this were Yosemite. This navigable waters, whether the land around it is owned by James Jones, the private person, or whether it's owned --  whether it's part of Yosemite Park. That's what it seemed to say to me. Now, there are two problems with what I just read. One is the third sentence and the word "unit." And the second problem is the NPS, the National Park Service, is it really all of Yosemite, you know, with that private thing or is it just the public part? Now, that's at least a sorry. I shouldn't have got into it. It's too complicated. Skip the question. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Why don't you take --  the --  the rest of us are interested in your answer to Justice Breyer. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Ms. Kovner.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, before you get to that, could we begin with what the Ninth Circuit decided? You're entitled to defend the judgment on any ground that you like, but --  that was presented below, but the only issue we have to --  we have to reach is the correctness of the Ninth Circuit's decision. Now, I understand what the Ninth Circuit to have held, to be this, that the hovercraft rule is not barred by the second sentence of Section 103(c) of ANILCA, because the hovercraft rule does not apply only in Alaska, because it applies throughout the country. Is that --  that's a correct understanding of what they held?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, no. I want to -- I understand the -- the holding -- and I -- I stand ready to be corrected -- to be what I stated: That the hovercraft rule is not barred because it isn't Alaska-specific. And, I mean, you filed a 58-page brief and, as I read it, you didn't get to the reason that the Ninth Circuit based its decision on until page 49, and you devoted exactly a paragraph to it. And why don't you concede that it's wrong? It's a ridiculous interpretation, is it not? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: If it's wrong. And -- and -- and walk it through, their argument, and tell me why they are wrong. Alderson Reporting Company I think they start with that Federal lands, as defined under the statute, are only lands that the U.S. has title to. Do you take --  do you disagree with that? And if so, why?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: How? Read the statute --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: --  and --  and --  and tell me how --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: --  in the statute --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: --  you can read it more broadly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm going --  I'm in the definition section.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, in other words, the interests aren't the title. This is subsidiary. It's -- it's water that the U.S. holds title to and interests in that water, even though they are not reflected in the title?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: It has to hold title to the interest.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, that's where I kind of stumbled in your argument, because you're not claiming title to the submerged land. It's clear that's in the State --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- right? Alderson Reporting Company You're -- you -- you rely on the reserved water right. Is that ever expressed as "title," as opposed to a -- the words -- "usufructuary right"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes, but holding title to that is different from holding title to the water.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And you're -- you're telling us that the river, that the government holds title to the river. It doesn't. It has usufructuary rights in the river.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's different from holding title to the water.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, it's just a -- I'm sorry to pause --  pause there. I understood with reserve water doctrine is usually, you know, we need water to do this, so we get --  we have a reserve right to percent of the water, or the initial flow, or whatever. I've never thought of it as a basis for general regulatory authority.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm with you so far. That gets you to regulating the waters in Federal -- in --  in --  in Federal units, because the U.S. under ANILCA only controls lands within the conservation units that are public lands.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: In the United States. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So --  and does the no-hovercraft rule apply to the nonpublic lands? Is that the position you're taking, that you have the right to regulate that as well?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Then --  then --  then I'm completely wrong. Then what the right --  then --  then I was totally wrong. I --  I thought that the argument was that --  just to go to my Yosemite analogy --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: --  that the hovercraft rule was like a rule that applies to all of Yosemite, say a campfire rule that applies even to John Jones's house.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I mean, it could be the navigable waters. It wouldn't be John Jones's fireplace. Alderson Reporting Company But if that -- if that's your argument, I was wrong.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I thought the navigable waters are not. They're on John Jones's property. But you still have the authority to regulate them, because the regulation that does it is not a regulation that applies solely to public lands.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is that right? Because you just seemed to say the opposite a minute ago.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, navigable waters that are within the boundaries of the National Park Service.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That's like John Jones's house in Yosemite.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The fireplace reg applies to him, even though his is a private house, because it's within the boundary of Yosemite.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Am I right or not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Either way, you say you win. Either they are Federal lands and this is part of a reg that applies to Federal lands; or they are not Federal lands, in which case this reg applies to both nonfederal and -- I mean nonpublic lands and public lands. So it's not within the second sentence. Is that your argument?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but if that's right, I mean, it -- it -- it's right because the question is do these things apply solely to public lands. And you say, well, the second sentence doesn't matter because we say they don't apply solely to public Alderson Reporting Company lands. That's not a very significant protection for the inholders.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, you -- you want to talk about waters, and -- and after this question I won't say anything more on this, but is the Ninth Circuit's holding limited to waters? The -- the State of Alaska on page and of their brief cite a notice in the Federal Register by the Park Service in which they defend the regulation of nonfederal oil and gas activities on the basis of Sturgeon, on the ground that Section 103(c) of ANILCA applies only to Alaska-specific regulations. And since these are not Alaska-specific, those -- those regulations apply. So they understand it to apply to something more than just navigable waters.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: It's solely to apply to Alaska --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That's the whole --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: --  within such unit?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Solely to apply to nonpublic units to lands in Alaska.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Let's --  let's talk about your authority. I don't even get to the second sentence. I just get to the first sentence. The authority of the Park Service comes from the statute Alderson Reporting Company which authorizes the Secretary of Interior to, quote, "prescribe such regulations necessary or proper for the use and management of system units, including those concerning boating and other activities. Only here the CSU's are park system units." That's 13.013(c). As a result, non-Federal holdings unambiguously fall outside the scope of the Secretary's authority because of the first sentence. "Only those lands within the boundaries of any conservation system unit which are public lands as such term is defined in this Act shall be deemed to be included as a portion of such unit." If it's not within the unit, it's not within the basic authority of the Park Service to issue regulations, period. So you -- you have to show that -- I think the Federal government holds title to the water. I don't think you can show. Nobody holds title to the water.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Why? You're -- you're conceding that the waters are outside of that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I read that first sentence. It's very interesting, because the tone of voice is the only way I can deal with this case. Watch. Imagine we Alderson Reporting Company have a valley that's a public land, and that valley traverses the boundary of the unit. Some of it's inside and some of it's outside. Now, only those lands within the boundaries of any conservation system which are public -- within the boundaries of any conservation system which are public lands shall be deemed to be included as a portion of the unit. So the only part of that valley that it's a portion of the unit is that part of the valley that's within the boundary of the unit. The part that's outside the boundary of the unit is not part of the unit.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is that what it -- I thought it must mean something like that. If it doesn't mean something like that, it means what Justice Scalia says. And then they're -- Joe Jones' house, the Indian reservation, none of it is part of the unit. But that can't be what it means, can it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Do you see what I -- are you following it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If it makes clear --  if it makes clear that private lands like Joe Jones' house are a part of the unit?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Within the boundaries of it. Ah, so distinction between being part of the unit and being within the boundaries of the unit.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You say this grant of authority in (b). You're quoting from the regulations --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: --  right from the statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What are you quoting from?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Can you tell me whether Alderson Reporting Company that statute violates this statute?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sorry. Go ahead.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: 7a? You're saying it's on page 7a?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's U.S.C. -- It's a regulation. It's not --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's not the numbering. It's -- it says regulations -- oh, I see. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The statute is addressing regulations.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's the subtitle in the statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And if I'm looking at the right section, I mean, I would have thought that that was key to your argument, because it says in these management plans what you need is a -- is a "description of privately owned areas which are within such unit." So it's clearly contemplating that there are these private areas that are within the unit. And then as you say, it goes on and says we want in these plans some idea of what regulations are going to be applying on those private lands within the unit.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What does -- you -- on page 24, and I think you have mentioned this several times, so -- you talk about this isn't a problem because your authority is circumscribed and you have the inholdings are -- have substantial protections against Alderson Reporting Company Park Service regulation. What -- what are those protections?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Do you -- do you think the statute that authorizes you to regulate is the one that says "the Secretary shall prescribe such regulations as the Secretary considers necessary or proper"? Would you --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but do you rely on that one? Because if you rely on that one, I don't see that it provides any protections at all.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So danger --  danger or harm, is that what it's limited to? Or could it be limited to scenic, environmental, noise impacts?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But is that true even if it's a --  the regulation is nation --  applicable nationwide?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So --  so if --  because if that's true, then I don't know what --  then you disagree with the Ninth Circuit on the meaning that it gave -- gives to the "solely" phrase?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No, but your authority is not limited if you get Chevron deference. If you get Chevron deference on determining what you think is necessary or proper, the idea that that's a substantial circumscription of your authority doesn't seem to me to be a valid one.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: More broadly? Interpret necessary or proper -- necessary or proper to mean necessary or proper? You think it's beyond belief that you're going to do that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Some might argue that your proposed regulations on oil contravene the intent of this provision. So assuming we do, how do you deal with that? Assuming some people do. I don't -- I don't know that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What can you do about why this provision that you -- you reproduce on 7a gets around the first section of 103(c)? This -- that provision allows regulation of waters within Service units, but the first section, as I read it, says that nonpublic land within the boundaries of -- of a CSU is not part of the CSU. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: is a general statute; it applies everywhere, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And --  and 3101, Section is specific to Alaska, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Isn't there a general rule that the specific governs the general?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So this general provision Alderson Reporting Company is limited by what Congress has said about Alaska. And that sentence says, "Only those lines within the boundaries of any CSU which are public lands shall be deemed to be included as a portion of such unit."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And if you read that back into 100751, it seems to me the Park Service doesn't have jurisdiction.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Go --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The regulation itself says, it says water --  "Hovercraft regulation applies to, quote, 'waters subject to the jurisdiction of the United States within the boundaries of the National Park Alderson Reporting Company Service.'"

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And then the National Park Service somewhere has a definition that equates it with the unit. The National Park Service is defined identically to system units. That's at U.S.C. and So if we -- Justice Scalia's point is this seems to take the private land, the in-holdings, and say they're not part of the unit; only the public lands are part of the unit --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- and then the Hovercraft Regulation applies only to the unit.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And that's -- that -- isn't that the point? Yes. That's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- the point.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What's the response to that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Exactly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Ah.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So you're saying it applies within -- it is within the boundaries of the unit, although the unit consists of just the public land. Who drafted this? This is -- (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, the specific would Alderson Reporting Company overcome the general. So if Congress passed a new statute, it could limit or expand as it chose, correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Let's say that part of a river is within a CSU. And do you read this statute to mean that the --the Park Service could regulate boating miles downstream from that part of the --  on that river, because it's relating to waters that are within the CSU?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Are you satisfied with this holding --  imaginary --  but the Ninth Circuit's wrong. Two, the second sentence does not bar this regulation. Three, there are other possible arguments; we send it back for reconsideration as to whether those arguments are good or bad.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: They --  they --  we're saying that the second sentence, which is what they're talking about primarily in the briefs, the second sentence of (c) --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: --  "no lands which," et cetera, you're right about that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You're right about --  I mean I imagine --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Then as to this first sentence, which I --  I don't think I focused on, particularly, we say go back and argue that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: No. That's you winning. (Laughter.) I think Justice Alito has been asking you this question from the beginning.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: What do you think the Ninth Circuit meant? And do you agree with its interpretation? As he pointed out --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: --  you spent pages of your brief arguing other things --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: --  putting you to the test.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: All right. So what do you think it held?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Do you think the Ninth Circuit was right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So if there's a rule that applies to conservation --  it applies to Alaska, and it applies to the National Mall, that would be that you can't have a Hovercraft in Alaska or in the tidal basin. Under the Ninth Circuit's --  the Ninth Circuit's rationale, that would be --  103 --  103(c) wouldn't buy that.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Findley, you have two minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Just in the two minutes, can you address the very last point the Solicitor General made, please?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank Case is submitted.
